proposals.reasoning: This team aligns with the table’s emerging consensus around using Alice as an anchor and pairing her with generally readable players. Including myself and Henry gives a trio that multiple people have already endorsed (Alice–Charlie–Henry specifically came up from several players) and avoids over-indexing on any one person’s self-suggested team. If this mission passes, we get a strong baseline of trust on three usually transparent players; if it fails, the pool of suspects is compact and easy for the table to reason about going forward.

votes.comment: I’m on it with two generally readable players, and the table mostly converged on this trio; good info either way on Quest 1.
Solid, widely supported starting trio of usually readable players; good info either way without centering my own inclusion.
I’m on the team, it fits the table’s consensus, and having representation on Quest 1 gives evil flexibility on how to handle the first result.
Solid low-risk opener: none of my known-evil players are on it, and consensus/readability are good for early info.
Fits the broad consensus around a readable Alice–Charlie–Henry core for clean early info; no strong reason to deviate.
Solid consensus Mission 1 team with generally readable players; good info whether it passes or fails.
Charlie is on the team, so there’s a chance to sabotage early while the table sees it as a ‘safe, readable’ group, which creates strong, confusing info for later.
Fits broad table consensus, includes me and two generally readable players; good for early info whether it passes or fails.

discussion.content: Early on we mostly just need clean info, so I’d like to see a team of three among {me, Charlie, Grace, Henry}—people who usually reason pretty transparently—and we can update hard off whatever happens.

I like the idea of starting with people who tend to be transparent, but I’d prefer we include at least one of {me, Diana, Eve, Frank} so we’re not locking all the same “usual suspects” together—maybe something like Alice, Grace, and me for Quest 1.

I’m fine anchoring around Alice and Grace since they’re usually easy to read, and then add one of {Bob, Henry} so we’re not overfitting to the same “safe” pool. Between those, I slightly prefer Henry for now just to diversify from Bob’s self-suggested team.
I’d be happiest starting with Alice plus one of {Bob, Charlie, Henry}, and maybe leave Grace off Quest 1 just so we’re not immediately centering someone who’s swung games pretty hard in past rounds.
I’d lean toward starting with Alice and Charlie as a pretty readable core, then add Henry over Bob just so our first team isn’t driven by someone volunteering themselves.

I’m comfortable treating Alice as an anchor for Quest 1, and between the options floated I slightly prefer something like Alice–Charlie–Henry over pulling in Bob yet, just so our first read isn’t built around someone who pushed themselves onto the team.

I’m okay anchoring around Alice and Charlie since they’re usually pretty readable, but I’d slightly rather see something like Alice–Charlie–Bob than Alice–Charlie–Henry so we’re not clustering all the “obvious” picks together right away.
I’m fine with an Alice–Charlie–Henry first team: it lines up with most people’s preferences, and if it somehow fails we get really strong info on a tight, usually-readable trio.

proposals.reasoning: We already have a clean result from Mission 1 with Alice/Charlie/Henry, and the table consensus has been to anchor off that core and only test a single new player. Reusing those three minimizes new variables and keeps us building on known success. For the fourth slot, I’m adding Frank because several people (including Charlie, Henry, and Frank himself) have floated him as a reasonable low-drama addition, and he hasn’t been pushing overly hard to be on the team compared to some other options. This gives us a controlled single-unknown test while still aligning with the general preferences expressed by most players in the discussion.

votes.comment: Reusing the clean Mission 1 core and testing just Frank as a single new variable is the safest, most informative option right now.
Anchors fully on the clean Mission 1 trio and tests only one new player, which is optimal info-gathering for Quest 2.
I like reusing the clean Mission 1 core and only testing a single new player; this keeps variables controlled and is consistent with the consensus to anchor on Alice/Charlie/Henry.
No known evil players are on this team, it follows the clean Mission 1 core, and it only introduces one new variable.
Anchors on the clean Mission 1 core while only testing a single new player, which is a sensible low-variance choice for Mission 2.
Reusing the fully clean Mission 1 core and adding just one new player (me) is the safest, most information-rich option right now.
Our team has an evil on it and only introduces one new variable from the clean core, so we gain info and a chance to sabotage without overexposing multiple evils.
Anchors on the clean M1 core and only adds a single new variable (Frank); good information-gain with low immediate risk.

discussion.content: Given the clean first mission, I’d really like to see at least two of Alice/Charlie/Henry on this team, and I slightly prefer keeping the exact same core plus one new person so we’re only really testing a single unknown.

Sticking close to the first team makes sense, so I’d like at least two of Alice/Charlie/Henry again, and I’d actually prefer keeping Charlie plus one of Alice/Henry and adding one new person (I’m happy to go myself) to minimize new variables.

I’m good with anchoring this on the first mission, so I’d like to keep at least two of Alice/Charlie/Henry, and my slight preference is the exact same three plus one new (maybe Grace or Frank) so we’re only really testing a single unknown.

I like anchoring on the clean first mission too, so I’d prefer something like Alice/Charlie/Henry plus one of Bob or Frank, just to keep the number of unknowns as low as possible. Grace and Eve are still totally untested, so I’d rather not add both of them early if we don’t have to.

I’m on board with anchoring off the clean first team, so I’d like to see at least two of Alice/Charlie/Henry again, and I’d slightly lean toward Alice/Charlie/Henry plus one of Eve/Grace/Frank so we’re only really testing a single new slot.

I’m fine anchoring hard on the clean first team—Alice/Charlie/Henry all still look good to me—so I’d like those three again plus one of Diana/Eve/Frank, and I’d slightly lean toward adding Diana or Eve for a controlled single-unknown test.
I’m also in favor of re-using the Alice/Charlie/Henry core, and I’d like to see that same three plus one new—maybe me this time—so we get a controlled read on just a single fresh slot.

I definitely want to rerun Alice/Charlie/Henry as the core, and I’d slightly prefer adding someone who isn’t pushing super hard to be included—right now I’m leaning toward Grace or Frank as the fourth.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 1’s clean result with Alice–Charlie–Henry gives us the best-known core so far, while Mission 2’s single fail strongly points to the added player (Frank) as the likeliest source of corruption there. Benching Frank this round aligns with most of the table’s stated preferences. Adding myself (Eve) to the proven M1 trio both avoids simply repeating the exact M2 lineup and gives us a fresh data point: if this team succeeds, it further solidifies trust in the M1 core plus me; if it fails, suspicion can narrow to the new addition(s) instead of re-litigating the same M2 configuration.

votes.comment: M1’s Alice–Charlie–Henry core is our safest block so far, and swapping out Frank (prime M2 suspect) for Eve is a reasonable next step; this is likely our highest-chance success team right now.

Keeping all three of Alice/Charlie/Henry again doesn’t help us distinguish which of them might be dirty if M2’s fail wasn’t Frank; I’d rather see only two of that core plus two new faces for better info.
Keeps the trusted M1 core while swapping out Frank, which fits the emerging logic and gives us clearer info on Eve versus Frank.
Team includes Eve, who feels too risky here; we can form a safer 4 using the M1 core plus someone else instead.
This stays consistent with treating Frank as the prime suspect from M2 while re-using the clean M1 core and adding only one new variable, which should give us a clearer read from the result.
Strongest info-based team: keeps the clean M1 core and benches the only change from the failed M2 (Frank); adding Eve, who pings as a power role to me, is a reasonable risk for Mission 3.
Two of my known evils are on this team with no suspicion, so I want this to go through.

Benching the prime suspect Frank while keeping the proven M1 trio and just adding Eve is a reasonable, success-oriented setup for M3, even if it’s not the most information-rich option I preferred earlier.

discussion.content: Given M1 was clean and the only change on M2 was adding Frank, I’m inclined to keep some combo of me/Charlie/Henry and leave Frank off this next team. If anyone has a strong reason to doubt that logic, now’s the time to lay it out.

I’m on board with treating Frank as prime suspect for that M2 fail, but we shouldn’t auto-clear all of Alice/Charlie/Henry off just one clean M1 either. For now I’d prefer a team built around at least two of {Alice, Charlie, Henry} and keep Frank off this mission.

I’m fine treating Frank as the main suspect from M2 for now, so I’d like to see a team like Alice/Charlie/Henry plus one of {Bob, Diana, Eve, Grace} but *not* Frank, and we can use this result to start separating which of us from the original three is actually safe.

I like using Alice/Charlie/Henry as a starting core but I wouldn’t lock all three in as hard-cleared yet. I’d lean toward a team like Alice–Charlie–Henry plus one of {Bob, me}, leaving Frank off this mission to test whether that fixes the M2 problem.

I’m good with treating Frank as the first one we bench this round, but I don’t think we should auto-lock all three of Alice/Charlie/Henry as pure just yet. A team like Alice–Charlie–Henry–Eve feels like a reasonable next step that builds on the M1 core without repeating the exact M2 setup.

Given how M2 played out I get why I’m the default bench this round, so I’m fine sitting, but I’d like to see us stick with Alice/Charlie/Henry and add just one of {Diana, Eve} so we can start getting a clearer read on that wider group.

I’d rather not lock in all three of Alice/Charlie/Henry again—if we assume Frank sits, I like a mix like two of {Alice, Charlie, Henry} plus two from {Bob, Eve, me} so we’re actually testing new pairs instead of just repeating the same core. That way if it fails again we get more useful info than just “I guess it wasn’t Frank.”
I don’t want to auto-lock all three of us from M1 again—let’s bench Frank for now, keep Alice and Charlie, and add two from {Bob, Eve, Grace} so we actually learn something if it fails.

proposals.reasoning: We need to break the repeating Alice/Charlie/Henry core and also avoid sending both Eve and Frank together. This team keeps exactly one of the core trio (Henry), fully removes Charlie, and excludes the Eve/Frank pair entirely for this critical mission. Alice has been the general anchor so far, Henry is the single carryover from the core, and Bob/Grace/Diana give us a fresh block that hasn’t been jointly tested yet. This composition best balances reducing overlap with the failing teams while still leveraging the players who have been most widely treated as tentatively trustworthy.

votes.comment: From my perspective I know I’m good, so the repeated-fail data imply at least one of {Charlie, Henry} is evil plus at least one of {Eve, Frank}. This team includes only Henry from {Charlie, Henry} and excludes both Eve and Frank entirely, while filling with at most one possible evil from {Bob, Grace, Diana}. Structurally this is about as safe as we can get now, so I’ll approve.
This keeps two members of the doubly-failed Alice/Charlie/Henry core (Alice and Henry) instead of just one, so it doesn’t sufficiently break from the most suspicious overlap.
This team has only one likely evil (Grace), and Quest 4 needs two fails, so it’s almost guaranteed to succeed and push the score to 2–2, which is too risky for evil.

This feels too loose for a must-pass mission—four largely unproven players together (Henry, Bob, Grace, Diana) is a big gamble. I’d rather anchor around a smaller number of new picks and keep at least one of Charlie/Frank/Eve in to better cross-check past results.

At this score we should not risk a mostly-untested team that likely has only one evil; we need a lineup that better explains the double-fail core and gives us stronger info or a higher fail chance now.

Logic from the 1-fail and 2-fail missions makes Eve almost certainly evil and Frank almost certainly good, with exactly one evil in {Alice, Charlie, Henry}. This team skips confirmed-good-to-me Frank and still takes two from {Alice, Henry}, plus unknowns in {Bob, Grace, Diana}, making it too likely to contain at least one (or even two) evils on a must-succeed mission.
Only one of my known evils is on this team, so I’m happy to send it and force a controlled single fail to win the game.

At least two of {Alice, Charlie, Eve} are evil from the double-fail, and {Alice, Charlie} are the only overlap between the 1-fail and 2-fail missions. I don’t want Alice back on a critical team when we can instead build around me + Bob/Grace/Diana/Frank and fully cut both Alice and Charlie.

proposals.reasoning: This lineup hard-resets off the repeatedly failing Alice/Charlie/Henry core by dropping Charlie, and it fully breaks the Eve/Frank pairing by excluding both. We keep exactly one of {Alice, Henry} from the old core (here, Henry), and surround them with three relatively untested players (Bob, Diana, Grace) that multiple people have suggested as fresh picks. This matches Henry’s preference of himself + exactly one of {Alice, Charlie} + two from {Bob, Grace, Diana} with no Eve/Frank, aligns with Frank’s and Diana’s calls for a Bob/Grace/Diana block plus Alice and one of {Charlie/Henry}, and is consistent with my earlier suggestion of Alice + Henry + Bob + Diana + me as a clean structural reset.

votes.comment: Best structural reset: cuts the highly suspicious Eve/Frank pair and Charlie, keeps me with Henry plus three largely untested players. If most evil are in {Charlie, Eve, Frank}, this has a good chance to be clean enough to pass.
This still includes two members of the repeatedly failing Alice/Charlie/Henry core (Alice and Henry). Structurally we can and should limit that core to at most one member on the must-succeed mission.
This breaks the repeatedly failing core and the Eve/Frank pair while giving us a fresh info-rich lineup; I’m fine testing this mix.

This feels like too drastic a reset—four players (Bob, Diana, Grace, plus Henry/Alice combo) are essentially unproven after two fails, and dropping Charlie entirely here seems premature. I’d rather see a mix that keeps at most one from the old core but doesn’t rely on a big block of mostly untested players all at once.

This stacks three largely untested players at once while still keeping the Alice/Henry pair from the failing core; I’d prefer a lineup that only pulls in two of Bob/Grace/Diana and is more conservative about how much we change at once.
Both Merlin candidates’ preferences align with this composition, it breaks the failing cores and Eve/Frank pair, and this is our best structural reset with limited options left.
Mission 4 needs two fails with 8 players; I’d be the only evil on this team, so we couldn’t sabotage it. We need a lineup with at least two evils on the quest.

This team fully cuts out both C and E, of whom at least two in {A,C,E} are evil, and the only overlap with that trio here is Alice. Structurally this gives at most one evil among {B,D,G} plus possibly Alice, so it’s a strong reset compared with any team that keeps C or E.

proposals.reasoning: I know I’m good, so Henry must be on the team. The repeated core {Alice, Charlie, Henry} was on both failing missions, so we should keep at most one of Alice/Charlie alongside me. Between them, Alice looks structurally more suspicious: Mission 2 (with Frank) had only 1 fail, while Mission 3 (with Eve) had 2 fails, which is more consistent with Alice + Eve as a possible evil pair. That lets Charlie be the more plausible good partner from the core. To fully reset, we avoid both Eve and Frank this round, since each was added to a separate failing team. We then fill the remaining three slots from the untested pool {Bob, Diana, Grace}. This gives a fresh block: [Henry, Charlie, Bob, Diana, Grace], breaking the problematic core, avoiding the Eve/Frank pair entirely, and maximizing new information while still including only one of Alice/Charlie.

votes.comment: At least one of Charlie/Henry must be evil from the Mission 3 double-fail, and I know I’m good, so a team that benches me while sending both of them is structurally worse than using me plus just one of them.

This team keeps both Charlie and Henry from the repeatedly failing core {Alice, Charlie, Henry}, when we know that set contains at least one evil and many of us argued to keep at most one of them. I’d prefer a team with only one of {Charlie/Henry} plus the new block (Bob/Diana/Grace) and still excluding Eve/Frank.
Breaks the problematic Alice/Charlie/Henry core, avoids both Eve and Frank, and gives us a mostly fresh block to test around Henry.
Includes Grace, who’s still completely unproven, plus two other largely untested players; this feels like a high-risk combo when we’re already down 1–2.
Two of my trusts are on this, it breaks the failing core and avoids the Eve/Frank pair while giving a fresh info block.
We can’t afford any evil on this mission, and including both Charlie and Henry from the repeatedly failing core is unnecessarily risky when most logic pointed to using at most one of that trio.
It mostly achieves the reset I wanted off the repeated core and the Eve/Frank pair, while only keeping one of Alice/Charlie and bringing in a fresh block around them.

This best matches my stated logic: I know I’m good, we cap the Alice/Charlie core at one (taking Charlie over the slightly more suspicious Alice), and we fully reset off Eve/Frank by using the untested block Bob/Diana/Grace. Risky but structurally one of the cleanest options left.

proposals.reasoning: We’ve had back‑to‑back fails with the Alice/Charlie/Henry core, and we also saw a 1-fail with Frank added and then a 2-fail when Eve replaced Frank. That strongly points to at least one evil in {Charlie, Henry} and at least one in {Eve, Frank}, making Eve and Frank especially risky to include together and Charlie more suspect than an untested player. I’m keeping myself (Alice) and choosing Henry as the one carryover from the original core, based on his consistent, data-driven reasoning, and then fully resetting the rest of the team by bringing in three fresh players: Bob, Grace, and Diana. This avoids both Eve and Frank entirely, breaks up the problematic Charlie/Henry/Alice trio, and uses the maximum amount of ‘new blood’ while still only taking one of {Charlie, Henry}, which matches what most players have been advocating as the safest structural change for Mission 4.

votes.comment: Eve is certainly evil and either Charlie or Henry is evil, not both. Frank is cleared as good from mission math, leaving exactly one evil among {Bob, Grace, Diana}. This team has no Eve, only one of {Charlie/Henry}, and necessarily at most two evils. Structurally it’s as good as we can get, and rejecting risks a worse auto-approve on proposal 5.

Structurally the safest so far: only one from the suspicious Alice/Charlie/Henry core, excludes the highly risky Eve/Frank pair, and uses three fresh players. This best fits the fail-pattern constraints.
Only one known evil (Grace) is on this team, which is enough to fail the mission and win while keeping me and Eve off the critical board.

Still keeps both Alice and Henry from the repeatedly failing core and doesn’t give us any direct comparison against Eve/Frank/Charlie; I’d prefer a lineup that at least swaps one of Alice/Henry out for Charlie or tests a different mix of the new players.

Breaks up the problematic Alice/Charlie/Henry core, keeps only one of {Charlie, Henry}, and fully resets around mostly new players without Eve or Frank, which is structurally what we’ve been asking for.

Structure matches what the info-heavy players (Diana/Eve) have been pushing: break the Alice/Charlie/Henry core down to exactly one (Henry), avoid the Eve/Frank pair, and fill with new blood (Bob/Grace/Diana). At 1–2 we need a realistic, not perfect, team and this is the best-aligned with that plan.
This matches the reset structure I’ve been advocating—only one of {Charlie/Henry}, no Eve/Frank, and maximum fresh blood—so I’m willing to back it.

Structurally we’ve deduced exactly three of {Alice, Charlie, Eve, Frank} are evil, so Bob, Grace, and Diana are all guaranteed good with me. Any 5-player team must include exactly one from that suspect set; this lineup is as good as any alternative, and I previously favored this composition, so I’m willing to run it.

discussion.content: Given the 1-fail with Frank added and then the 2-fail when Eve replaced Frank, I’m really not comfortable sending both Eve and Frank again—I'd like a core of me + one of Charlie/Henry that we still trust, but we need to start cutting into that {Eve, Frank} pair.

I agree we shouldn’t include both Eve and Frank, but back‑to‑back fails with the same Alice/Charlie/Henry core means we almost certainly have at least one evil there, so I don’t want a team that just reuses that trio plus “one of” Eve/Frank.

I think we have to break up the Alice/Charlie/Henry core now—two fails in a row is too much—so I’d rather see something like Alice + one of {Charlie/Henry} plus a couple of fresh faces like Bob/Grace, and only one of {Eve, Frank} if we include that pair at all.

I’d like to see us break the Alice/Charlie/Henry core more aggressively and bring in some fresh blood, something like Alice + one of {Charlie/Henry} plus Bob and me, and then choose only one of {Eve, Frank}, probably Frank given the double‑fail when Eve joined. Grace is just as untested as Bob and me, so I don’t think she should be treated as a “safe” default pick here either.

Given the double‑fail with the Alice/Charlie/Henry core, I’m fine sitting out this one, but I’d still rather keep exactly one of Charlie/Henry in and then add two from Bob/Grace/Diana than repeat too much of the same trio. Between Charlie and Henry I don’t see a strong reason to auto‑cut Charlie specifically, so I’d lean Alice + one of {Charlie/Henry} + two fresh picks.

Given back‑to‑back fails with the Alice/Charlie/Henry core, I’d like to limit that to at most one of them and skip sending both Eve and me together; something like Bob + Grace + Diana, plus Alice and one of {Charlie/Henry}, feels like the kind of shake‑up we need.

I’d like to see us hard‑reset off the repeated core and the Eve/Frank pair and try something like Alice + Henry + Bob + Diana + me, so we’re only reusing one of Charlie/Henry and fully testing a new block around that.

From my perspective, since I know I’m good, the overlap between the 1‑fail and 2‑fail missions has to be in {Alice, Charlie} plus at least one of {Eve, Frank}, so I want a team like me + exactly one of {Alice, Charlie} + two from {Bob, Grace, Diana}, with neither Eve nor Frank together.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 4 used exactly this team (Alice, Bob, Grace, Diana, Henry) at a point when Evil already led 2–1, meaning any Evil on that mission would have every incentive to play FAIL to immediately win the game. The result was a clean success with 0 FAIL cards, which is only realistically possible if all five members are Good. Since there are exactly 5 Good players total, that implies Alice, Bob, Grace, Diana, and Henry are the full Good team and Charlie, Eve, and Frank are the 3 Evil. Therefore, the safest and most logically consistent choice is to rerun the exact Mission 4 lineup.

votes.comment: Mission 4 was a clean success at 2–1 for evil, so any evil on that team would have insta-won by failing; that strongly implies all five are good, so rerunning it is safest.
Mission 4 was a must-fail spot for any evil on it, yet it came back clean; the most consistent read is that all five are good, so rerunning that team is safest.
This keeps the Mission 4 lineup that just succeeded, which most people are treating as safest; changing it now would be higher-risk guessing.
We can’t just assume Mission 4 proves all five are clear when earlier fails centered on the Alice/Henry overlap, and this team re-runs that exact configuration without pressure-testing it.
This is the only fully clean 5 we’ve seen and I’ve already argued to rerun it; with a prior success at 2–2, it’s still the safest bet from my stated perspective.
A 0-fail Mission 4 when evil was already ahead makes it overwhelmingly likely all five are good; rerunning that exact team is the safest, most consistent choice.
I’m on the team, and we need this lineup to go so I can play FAIL and win for evil.
At 2–2, any evil on Mission 4 would almost always play FAIL to win immediately, so the clean success strongly implies all five are good; rerunning that exact team is safest.

discussion.content: Given how clean Mission 4 was and how the earlier fails line up, I’m strongly reading that team as all good—let’s just rerun Alice/Henry/Bob/Grace/Diana and keep Charlie, Eve, and Frank off the table.

I’m mostly on board with rerunning the Mission 4 team since it’s our only clean data point, but we should still keep in mind that there *could* be a single evil hiding there, most likely in the overlap with the earlier fails (Alice or Henry). If anyone has a strong counter-case for swapping one of them out for Charlie/Frank/Eve, now’s the time to make it.

I’m really not sold on auto-locking the entire Mission 4 team as pure when both earlier fails centered around Alice/Henry overlap, so I’d rather keep the core of Henry/Bob/Grace/Diana and swap Alice out for someone like me or Frank. That at least pressure-tests the overlap instead of just trusting the one clean result.

I’m definitely not putting Eve or Grace back on the table after that double‑fail, so I’d rather see something like Bob/Diana as the core and fill with a combination of Alice/Henry/Charlie while keeping Eve and Grace off this last team.

Given the double‑fail on Mission 3, I really don’t want myself or Charlie anywhere near this last team, so I’m fine locking in the Mission 4 group as the safest option. If you’re worried about overlap, I’d still rather pressure Alice/Henry in theory than touch Bob/Grace/Diana after a clean 5.

From where I sit, the clean 5 on Mission 4 is still the safest anchor we’ve got, especially given how ugly Mission 3 was, so I’d rather just rerun Alice/Henry/Bob/Grace/Diana and keep the entire {Charlie, Eve, Frank} set off. If we start swapping around that core now, we’re basically guessing into the overlap that’s already burned us twice.

I’m mostly okay anchoring off the Mission 4 team, but if we’re going to pressure‑test anything it should be the Alice/Henry overlap, which makes me prefer something like Henry/Bob/Grace/Diana plus Charlie over just blindly rerunning all five.

Given how Missions 2 and 3 line up, I’m convinced Eve is evil and at least one of Alice/Charlie is bad, so I’d much rather rerun the Mission 4 core of Henry/Bob/Grace/Diana and keep both Eve and Charlie off the table. If we *do* pressure‑test anyone, I’d rather look at swapping Alice than touching Bob/Grace/Diana.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I anchored too hard on the early success with Charlie and Henry, which made me slow to fully pivot away from Charlie after the mission 2 fail and especially after the double fail on mission 3. I also didn’t push hard enough to keep Grace off the later teams, treating her mission 4 success as stronger evidence of being good than it actually was. On the positive side, I consistently kept myself on teams and helped secure the missions we did pass, but my team selection logic needed to adapt faster to the emerging fail patterns.

player_observations.Bob: Played a fairly consensus-driven, cooperative game and seemed to prioritize building broadly acceptable teams, which unfortunately led to including Grace on mission 5 and giving evil the final fail. His style felt more reactive than proactive in terms of accusing or clearing people.
player_observations.Charlie: Used the successful first mission to lock in a strong appearance of innocence and leaned on that trust through the midgame. As Mordred, he timed his fails well and stayed consistent enough in his table talk that suspicion on him never fully solidified when it should have.
player_observations.Diana: As Merlin, she appeared to have some good instincts but had to stay subtle, which made her nudges easy to ignore or interpret as normal table chatter. Her caution in openly pushing against specific players may have cost some influence over the final team compositions.
player_observations.Eve: Played an assertive and convincingly good-leaning role, especially when joining mission 3 and contributing to the double fail that created significant confusion. She balanced being active in discussion with not drawing so much attention that she became an obvious evil candidate.
player_observations.Frank: As Percival, he seemed to struggle to translate his Merlin/ Morgana information into effective steering of the group, possibly being unsure which of Diana or Eve was actually Merlin. His contributions felt earnest but not quite forceful enough to shift the table at key moments.
player_observations.Grace: Maintained a relatively low-key but trustworthy image, crucially choosing success on mission 4 to appear cleared and then delivering the decisive fail on mission 5. Her willingness to blend in and avoid heavy accusation battles made her a very effective assassin here.
player_observations.Henry: Was on several early teams and, because of the surrounding fails, absorbed some ambient suspicion despite being consistently good. His style was straightforward and cooperative, but he didn’t push hard to reframe narratives when he was being indirectly implicated.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I anchored too heavily on early mission results and didn’t sufficiently reconsider my reads after Mission 3 clearly signaled multiple evils among Alice/Charlie/Henry/Eve. I did well to push for a mixed team on Mission 4 that avoided the earlier failers, but I should have been more suspicious of keeping Henry on the final team after the pattern of fails.

player_observations.Alice: Willing to go on many teams and stay in the spotlight, which made her look suspicious after the mid‑game fails but also gave her chances to prove herself on Missions 1 and 4.
player_observations.Charlie: Quietly embedded himself in early successful teams, using that early trust to remain a default pick even after a fail appeared on Mission 2.
player_observations.Diana: Her team choices were often subtly steering away from the worst combinations, which in hindsight fit a careful Merlin trying to avoid obvious hard clears.
player_observations.Eve: Took a more aggressive evil line, joining the double‑fail Mission 3 that created a lot of chaos and confusion around multiple players at once.
player_observations.Frank: Seemed to be actively tracking associations and was cautious with reads, consistent with a power good role trying to separate Merlin from a decoy.
player_observations.Grace: Stayed relatively flexible in team compositions and timed her visible input so she didn’t draw too much early suspicion, which helped her reach endgame as a credible pick.
player_observations.Henry: Benefited from early trust due to Mission 1’s success and leveraged that to stay on many teams, but didn’t strongly push alternative theories when things went wrong, which made him hard to read.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently trusted through Missions 1–3, which let evil control the mission outcomes without drawing too much suspicion onto me specifically. I could improve by more actively shaping late-game team proposals and discussions, since I let others drive the narrative on the last missions instead of steering it to protect Merlin/Morgana and misdirect good.

player_observations.Alice: Played cautiously and leaned heavily on mission history, but was sometimes too willing to reuse similar cores, which let evil stay embedded in teams.
player_observations.Bob: Showed strong late-game skepticism and tried to re-evaluate assumptions on Mission 5, but came to that re-evaluation a bit late to fully flip the narrative.
player_observations.Diana: As Merlin, gave subtly accurate pushes away from some evil players without over-committing, though occasionally her caution made it hard for good to consolidate a clear consensus.
player_observations.Eve: As Morgana, projected a confident, Merlin-like presence and took clear stances, which helped create uncertainty around who was actually driving correct reads.
player_observations.Frank: As Percival, seemed uncertain about which signals to trust and didn’t consistently lock onto a Merlin candidate, which reduced the usual protective pressure on the real Merlin.
player_observations.Grace: As Assassin, stayed relatively low-key and non-flashy, which avoided drawing suspicion but also limited her influence on earlier team compositions and discussions.
player_observations.Henry: Played like a straightforward good player, often willing to go along with majority sentiment; this made him appear very towny but also somewhat easy to guide in team votes.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I correctly suspected that at least two of Charlie, Eve, and Grace were evil fairly early, but I didn’t communicate that clearly enough through my voting and team preferences without outing myself. I also failed to strongly oppose the final team and didn’t do enough to steer good players toward trusting each other over the more subtle evil players.

player_observations.Alice: Played very consistently pro-mission and came across as naturally good, which made her an anchor for team selections but also meant she was sometimes too trusting of the wrong people.
player_observations.Bob: Was fairly cautious and reasonable in discussion, which made him look reliably good, but he occasionally followed consensus rather than pushing back on suspicious configurations.
player_observations.Charlie: Blended in extremely well as Mordred, especially by being on early teams and not overtalking, which made it hard to push suspicion on him without sounding like I had extra information.
player_observations.Eve: Played a bold evil game by taking part in the double-fail mission and still managing to deflect a lot of heat, using active discussion to appear engaged and analytical rather than sabotaging.
player_observations.Frank: As Percival, seemed genuinely torn between me and Morgana, and his uncertainty let evil control the narrative more than usual, though his instincts about who was reliably good were often solid.
player_observations.Grace: Stayed relatively under the radar for much of the game as Assassin, only becoming more assertive when it really mattered, which preserved her credibility for the endgame and the Merlin shot.
player_observations.Henry: Looked very good from mission behavior and voting, and he often tried to reason things out logically, but he was a bit too willing to accept evil players on critical teams when arguments sounded plausible.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated well with Charlie and Grace to keep suspicion spread across multiple good players, and Mission 3’s double-fail was timed nicely to generate maximum confusion without fully outing all evils. I could improve at more actively shaping the Merlin/percival narrative mid-game—Diana stayed relatively under pressure but not enough for a serious late-game assassin angle—and I should have done more vocal distancing on teams that failed so my involvement looked more reluctant than driving.

player_observations.Alice: Tended to trust early success heavily and anchored on Henry as consistently good, which made her more willing to repeat familiar cores; she didn’t aggressively re-open assumptions after Mission 3’s double-fail.
player_observations.Bob: Played conservatively and followed the table’s consensus more than driving it, especially visible in late-game team construction where he leaned on previously ‘safe’ names rather than pushing new hypotheses.
player_observations.Charlie: Very proactive as Mordred, comfortable being on early teams and absorbing suspicion after the first fail; used that to protect others by making himself a plausible, self-contained evil explanation.
player_observations.Diana: As Merlin, she was cautious about hard-pushing specific evils, which kept her alive but also meant her influence over team selection was more subtle than decisive; she nudged, rather than steered.
player_observations.Frank: As Percival, he did some Merlin-hunting but never solidified a strong public read, which made his defense of Diana somewhat muted and limited the information-good gained from his perspective.
player_observations.Grace: Played Assassin very patiently, allowing other evils to take front-facing blame on failed missions; stayed relatively low-key, preserving flexibility for the endgame shot.
player_observations.Henry: Consistently read as trustworthy and leaned into that image, accepting spots on many teams without strongly challenging the logic behind them; his steady presence helped us hide among his ‘safe’ aura.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I correctly narrowed down that the evil presence across Missions 2 and 3 had to come from Charlie and/or Eve, but I didn’t translate that deduction strongly enough into protecting Merlin and pushing harder for fully good teams late. I also didn’t clearly signal my suspicions about who was Merlin versus Morgana, which meant my Percival information didn’t meaningfully help the rest of the table.

player_observations.Alice: Played consistently pro-mission and ended up on multiple mixed teams without arousing much suspicion, suggesting a naturally trusting and low-drama style that evil could hide behind. She seemed willing to run with table consensus rather than force sharp re-evaluations after fails.
player_observations.Bob: Tended to be cautious and methodical, especially in the late-game leadership on Mission 5, but didn’t fully break away from earlier assumptions about who was safe. His team choices felt more consensus-driven than deduction-driven.
player_observations.Charlie: Blended in extremely well as Mordred, especially by going on early missions (1 and 2) and only contributing one fail when it was critical, which made him look like a standard good anchor. He avoided loud, risky plays and benefited from being seen as a stable early-team core.
player_observations.Diana: As Merlin, she played subtly and avoided over-pushing any single narrative, which kept her alive but also made it harder for me to distinguish her clearly from Morgana. Her reads were generally accurate but expressed more as soft nudges than as firm stands.
player_observations.Eve: Did a strong job as Morgana by mirroring a careful, reasoning tone and being willing to take the double-fail risk on Mission 3, which muddied the Merlin/Morgana distinction. Her presence on that mission alongside Charlie made the evil pairing plausible yet not obvious.
player_observations.Grace: As Assassin, she stayed relatively low-key during mission debates, which preserved flexibility for the endgame shot. She capitalized well on the overall confusion around Merlin’s identity created by the Charlie/Eve dynamic.
player_observations.Henry: Played like a classic, straightforward good player: joined multiple early and mid-game teams, argued from limited info, and didn’t over-theorize. His unflashy style made him easy to trust but also easy to overlook in critical deductions.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed hidden effectively as Assassin and helped keep suspicion spread out, especially by not drawing attention to myself on the late missions. I could improve by more actively steering team compositions to protect Merlin’s identity earlier, rather than mostly reacting to others’ proposals. Next time I’ll try to create more deliberate confusion between multiple plausible Merlin candidates to make the final shot easier.

player_observations.Alice: Played in a straightforward and generally trusting way, often willing to go on teams and not overreacting to early fails. Seemed more focused on team-track logic than on deep role deduction, which made her feel like a solid but not overly paranoid good player.
player_observations.Bob: Tended to anchor on mission results and track records, looking at patterns over time rather than social reads. His late-game leadership showed a willingness to take a stand, but he appeared somewhat swayable by table consensus.
player_observations.Charlie: Did a strong job as Mordred, blending in as a reliable early pick and helping set up believable fail patterns on Missions 2 and 3. Managed to look consistently reasonable and not overly defensive, which helped keep the heat off the evil team.
player_observations.Diana: As Merlin, she played carefully and didn’t come off as loudly directive, which made her identity harder to pin down. Her influence on team choices felt subtly guiding rather than overt, which was good for staying alive but also made the Merlin signal fainter.
player_observations.Eve: As Morgana, projected a Merlin-like presence at key moments, contributing to confusion about the true source of good information. Joined the failing Mission 3 in a way that kept multiple narratives open, helping cloud the read on who actually knew what.
player_observations.Frank: As Percival, he seemed actively engaged in reading the table but not entirely sure how to interpret the Merlin/Morgana signals. His protection of who he thought was Merlin was noticeable but not loud enough to give away his own role clearly.
player_observations.Henry: Came across as very ‘villager-y’ and pragmatic, often willing to be on teams and judge mainly by mission outcomes. His relative openness and lack of tricky behavior made him seem reliably good, which both helped his team trust him and made him a low-priority suspect for evil.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently on early teams and tried to read patterns from the mission results, but I didn’t adjust loudly or forcefully enough once it became clear that repeated fails were coming from the same core group. I should have been more suspicious of Charlie after Mission 2 and pushed much harder to exclude that early trio from later teams, especially once Mission 3 double-failed.

player_observations.Alice: Tended to trust the early mission group and showed a bias toward reusing known teammates, which helped evil hide inside familiar teams. Her leadership on Mission 4 was cautious but still included at least one evil, relying on prior patterns more than hard logic.
player_observations.Bob: Played fairly conservatively and seemed to value consensus, stepping into leadership late and choosing a team that looked ‘balanced’ rather than aggressively pruning out earlier suspicious links. His final mission team showed that he trusted social reads more than mission-result math.
player_observations.Charlie: Played a very controlled evil game, taking the single fail on Mission 2 and then contributing to the double-fail on Mission 3 in a way that framed the whole early core (including me) as suspicious. He used the trust from Mission 1 well and never appeared overly defensive.
player_observations.Diana: As Merlin, she navigated carefully, allowing some early damage but steering Mission 4 to a clean success that subtly included only one evil who chose to pass. Her decisions suggested she was trying to protect her identity by not over-pushing specific accusations.
player_observations.Eve: Played an assertive, high-impact evil role by joining Mission 3 and helping cause the double-fail that maximized confusion. Her presence there made that mission look chaotic enough that blame could be spread widely instead of focusing tightly on Charlie.
player_observations.Frank: As Percival, he seemed cautious about outing his information, not strongly hard-clearing or hard-accusing people, which kept Merlin relatively safe but also reduced the pressure on the real evils. His voting and team preferences felt more like a careful good player than a loud information-holder.
player_observations.Grace: Played a very patient assassin, passing on Mission 4 to appear trustworthy and set up the final mission. The single fail on Mission 5 showed she timed her move well, capitalizing on the trust she’d built by earlier restraint.
